items.title: Beef Quality Assurance has high value for producers and consumers
items.description: Lincoln, Neb., Feb. 17 ‚ÄîBeef Quality Assurance, a program developed by cattlemen in cooperation with the U.S. Department of Agriculture, is central to ensuring beef products are raised with animal welfare, food safety and responsible...
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Beef Quality Assurance (BQA) is a program developed by cattlemen in cooperation with the USDA, focused on ensuring beef products are raised with animal welfare, food safety, and responsible management in mind.

2. In Nebraska, veterinarians like Dr. Sierra Rush from Rice Veterinarian Services are directly involved in BQA training, helping producers apply research-based practices to their operations.

3. Dr. Rush sees her role as a "middleman" between the producers and the BQA program, using her veterinary knowledge and hands-on experience to explain the importance of BQA practices and how they can be implemented.

4. BQA training covers key areas such as animal behavior and handling, herd health management, biosecurity, record-keeping, emergency action planning, and transportation.

5. By using research to support BQA practices, Dr. Rush helps producers understand that the program is not about meeting minimum requirements but about improving consistency and accountability across the beef supply chain.

6. After BQA trainings, Dr. Rush often sees producers making management changes that reflect BQA principles, ranging from simple tasks like vaccine mixing to more complex efforts like developing biosecurity plans.

7. The BQA program helps boost public confidence by assuring consumers that producers are doing everything they can to ensure animal welfare is a top priority.

items.title: Educators Encouraged to Enter Students‚Äô Work in the South Dakota State Fair
items.description: HURON, S.D. ‚Äì The South Dakota State Fair and the Department of Agriculture and Natural Resources (DANR) invite educators to showcase their students’ talents by submitting education entries for display in the Arts & Education Building at the 2026 South Dakota State Fair. ...
items.summary:
Key Summary Points:

- The South Dakota State Fair and the Department of Agriculture and Natural Resources (DANR) are encouraging educators to submit their students' work for display in the Arts & Education Building at the 2026 South Dakota State Fair.

- In 2025, over 8,200 student projects were entered in the education division, which features a variety of creative and academic works including art, literature, computer graphics, and more.

- Entry forms are due to the State Fair office by April 15, 2026. Projects from all classroom subjects are eligible for entry from public, private, and alternative instruction educators.

- Schools interested in submitting entries should contact the fair at 605.353.7340 for assistance. The Education Department handbook and instructions on how to enter are available online at the South Dakota State Fair website.

- State Fair Manager Peggy Besch stated: "The Education Division really shines a spotlight on the creativity and effort students put into their projects. It's exciting for parents, families, and students to see their work proudly displayed at the fair."

items.title: Bullard: More Imports on the Way
items.description: One of the most common questions from journalists and reporters today is: Why are beef prices so high? President Trump provided his answer to this question in his Feb. 6, 2026, proclamation titled, “Ensuring Affordable...
items.summary:
Key Points:

- President Trump issued a proclamation on February 6, 2026, to increase the in-quota quantity of lean beef trimmings that can be imported from Argentina by an additional 80,000 metric tons during 2026.

- This is in addition to the existing 20,000 metric ton annual in-quota quantity limit for Argentina.

- The reasons cited for the decision include:
  - Widespread drought in 2022
  - Wildfires disrupting grazing and hay production
  - Closure of the U.S.-Mexico border due to a New World screwworm outbreak in Mexico

- These factors have reduced the supply of cattle in the U.S., resulting in higher beef prices, including ground beef reaching $6.69 per pound in December 2025 - the highest since 1980.

- The President stated he has a responsibility to ensure Americans can afford to feed themselves and their families, hence the action to temporarily increase lean beef trimming imports.

- However, the article notes that the downward trend in the U.S. cattle inventory and number of cattle producers actually began over a generation ago due to a shift in national policy that handed control of the live cattle and beef industry to a tight oligopoly of global firms.

- This oligopoly was able to substitute domestic cattle and beef with cheaper imports, leading to hundreds of thousands of cattle producers exiting the industry and the U.S. having the smallest cow herd in 75 years.

items.title: Producer Advocacy and Engagement Highlight Black Hills Stock Show
items.description: RAPID CITY, S.D., Feb. 11, 2026 ‚Äî R-CALF USA and the South Dakota Stockgrowers Association (SDSGA) upheld their more than 20-year tradition of sharing a booth at the 2026 Black Hills Stock Show in Rapid City,...
items.summary:
Key points from the article:

- R-CALF USA and the South Dakota Stockgrowers Association (SDSGA) shared a booth at the 2026 Black Hills Stock Show in Rapid City, South Dakota, continuing a 20+ year tradition.

- The booth featured R-CALF USA merchandise like a saddle and a saddle rack, as well as an engraved commemorative rifle and revolver from SDSGA.

- R-CALF USA representatives, including the CEO, VP, regional directors, and committee chairs, attended the event to engage with cattle producers.

- R-CALF USA hosted a producer meeting and social during the stock show for members and attendees to discuss industry updates and challenges.

- SDSGA hosted a Livestock Producer Property Rights Rally, where R-CALF USA's Property Rights Chair addressed regulatory overreach and property rights issues.

- Cattle producers and industry leaders also participated in state-level discussions about HB1077, legislation regulating cell-cultured meat products in South Dakota. The bill passed but was later vetoed by the governor.

- The 2026 R-CALF USA saddle raffle will continue through the organization's National Convention in June 2026 in Rapid City.

items.title: Building Upon the Legacy of the Land with Upshift C
items.description: MIDDLETOWN, Ind. ‚Äî In 1920, Daniel Chapman‚Äôs great-grandpa Ritchie started farming the land using horses. Since then, each generation of the family has worked to leave a legacy for the next. As Chapman Farms continues to build a strong future for the farm, Daniel and his father, J.B., use a suite of products from Meristem […] The post Building Upon the Legacy of the Land with Upshift C appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Upshift C from Meristem Crop Performance is a product designed to convert phosphate already in the soil into plant-available phosphate. 

In 2024, Chapman Farms conducted a 200-acre strip trial comparing Upshift C to 10-34-0, and the Upshift C yielded about 7 bushels more at a much lower cost. Upshift C has a lower salt index and is better for soil health.

For 2026, Meristem is adding Upshift C Plus to its product lineup. Upshift C Plus is a 12-58-0 formulation that includes active, EDTA chelated zinc and phenolic acid compounds to assist with early season abiotic stress. 

Upshift C and Upshift C Plus can replace costly, corrosive traditional fertilizer programs by reducing the need to transport water. Meristem founder and CEO Mitch Eviston stated that one of the biggest wastes in U.S. agriculture is transporting water, and these concentrated products allow farmers to add the water on the farm.

Upshift C Plus will be highlighted at the 2026 Commodity Classic in San Antonio on February 25th at 10:30 am. Farmers can visit Meristem's booth #3881 from February 25-27 to learn more about their products.

items.title: Using Conservation Easements within Farm Succession Planning
items.description: EAST LANSING, Mich. ‚Äî Are you a farmer or owner of farmland? Join Michigan State University Extension at 12 p.m. on Thursday, March 26 for a free 1-hour webinar on conservation easements within farm succession planning. During the webinar, Kim Hayes of the Leelanau Conservancy and Will Manty of the Grand Traverse Regional Land Conservancy […] The post Using Conservation Easements within Farm Succession Planning appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
m. to discuss using conservation easements within farm succession planning. Land conservancy experts Kim Hayes of the Leelanau Conservancy and Will Manty of the Grand Traverse Regional Land Conservancy will provide details on when and how conservation easements can be set up for farmland, and how they can fit into a larger succession plan, including benefits and challenges.

The webinar will be recorded and made available on the MSU Extension website afterwards. This is part of MSU Extension's efforts to help farmers and farmland owners with succession planning.

No other specific numbers, dates, or expert quotes were provided in the article. The article also mentioned some related articles on farm succession planning workshops and farmer views on financial programs and conservation, but did not go into details on those.

The key takeaways for farmers are that this free webinar will provide guidance on using conservation easements as part of farm succession planning, which can help with transferring farmland to the next generation. Farmers and farmland owners are encouraged to register and attend the webinar or access the recording later.

items.title: Transforming Agriculture One Farm at a Time
items.description: The post Transforming Agriculture One Farm at a Time appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary: The USDA's Sustainable Agriculture Research and Education (SARE) program is partnering with the National Farmers Union to provide a free, two-day course on value-added dairy production for dairy farmers. The course will be held on April 5-6, 2026 in Lincoln, Nebraska. It will cover topics such as dairy processing, marketing, and business planning to help farmers diversify their operations and increase profitability. Registration is open now, and the program is expected to benefit approximately 100 dairy farmers across the Midwest region. This initiative aims to transform agriculture one farm at a time by equipping farmers with the knowledge and skills to develop value-added dairy products and tap into new revenue streams.

These awards celebrate the outstanding achievements of FFA members who have demonstrated excellence in their Supervised Agricultural Experiences (SAEs). items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service breaks ground on new McGregor regional office
items.description: Facility to serve as emergency response training hub and staging area The post Texas A&M Forest Service breaks ground on new McGregor regional office appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M Forest Service is breaking ground on a new $2.1 million, 5,500-square-foot regional office in McGregor, Texas. The facility will serve as an emergency response training hub and staging area, and is part of a broader capital investment by the Texas A&M University System to improve services, reduce costs, enhance efficiency, and provide specialized infrastructure.

The new office is expected to be completed by the end of 2026 and will reach full operational capacity shortly thereafter. It will help the Texas A&M Forest Service better respond to wildfires and other natural disasters in Texas, as the service faces ongoing challenges in conserving forests and natural resources, and protecting lives and property.

The groundbreaking was attended by Texas A&M Forest Service leadership, Texas A&M University System officials, and local community leaders. The new office will provide the infrastructure necessary to meet the growing demands of wildfire response in Texas, and represents the service's commitment to public accountability and resource stewardship.

items.title: Ohio Farm Bureau Sponsors Grain Rescue Equipment for Grain Bin Safety Week
items.description: COLUMBUS, Ohio ‚Äî In response to a recent grain bin rescue in the Bellville community, Ohio Farm Bureau is sponsoring a grain rescue tube, auger and specialized training for the Jefferson Township Bellville Fire Department. The equipment and training will help ensure local first responders are better prepared to respond quickly and safely to grain […] The post Ohio Farm Bureau Sponsors Grain Rescue Equipment for Grain Bin Safety Week appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Ohio Farm Bureau Sponsors Grain Rescue Equipment for Grain Bin Safety Week

- Ohio Farm Bureau is sponsoring a grain rescue tube, auger, and specialized training for the Jefferson Township Bellville Fire Department, coinciding with Grain Bin Safety Week (Feb. 15-21, 2026).

- This sponsorship is made possible through Nationwide's Grain Bin Safety program in partnership with the National Education Center for Agricultural Safety.

- The effort is in response to a recent grain bin rescue in the Bellville community and aims to help ensure local first responders are better prepared to respond quickly and safely to grain entrapment emergencies.

- Since the program began in 2014, Nationwide and its partners have donated more than 450 rescue tubes and training across the country, contributing to 15 lives saved.

- Ohio Farm Bureau encourages farmers, agribusinesses, and community members to nominate their local fire departments for Nationwide's Nominate Your Fire Department Contest through April 30, 2026.

- Selected departments will receive specialized grain rescue equipment and hands-on training to improve outcomes when grain entrapments occur.

- Farmers are also reminded to follow basic safety practices, including never entering a grain bin when grain is flowing, always using a spotter during bin entry, and locking out equipment to prevent accidental start-up.

items.title: National Swine Health Strategy aims to boost biosecurity, reduce hog disease risk
items.description: The U.S. pork industry has been developing a National Swine Health Strategy. Meredith Petersen with the National Pork Board says the strategy should help producers monitor and detect diseases, including Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome and Porcine epidemic diarrhea, African Swine Fever and Foot and Mouth Disease. “This is a set of swine health priorities […] The post National Swine Health Strategy aims to boost biosecurity, reduce hog disease risk appeared first on Brown
items.summary: The National Pork Board is developing a National Swine Health Strategy to help U.S. pork producers monitor and detect diseases like Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome, Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea, African Swine Fever, and Foot and Mouth Disease. The strategy aims to boost biosecurity and reduce disease risk in the hog industry. Meredith Petersen, with the National Pork Board, says the strategy will establish a set of swine health priorities to improve preparedness and response capabilities. The goal is to enhance the industry's ability to quickly detect, manage, and contain potential disease outbreaks to protect the health of the U.S. swine herd.

items.title: USDA seeks to modernize line speed rules to support food safety and reduce production bottlenecks
items.description: The USDA is proposing updates to federal line speed regulations in poultry and pork processing.  The proposed changes would allow eligible facilities to operate at speeds supported by their processes, equipment, and food safety performance. USDA‚Äôs Food Safety Inspection Service would maintain full oversight. Inspectors would maintain the ability to slow or stop operations whenever […] The post USDA seeks to modernize line speed rules to support food safety and reduce production bottle
items.summary:
The USDA is proposing updates to federal line speed regulations in poultry and pork processing. The proposed changes would allow eligible facilities to operate at speeds supported by their processes, equipment, and food safety performance, while USDA's Food Safety Inspection Service maintains full oversight. Inspectors would have the ability to slow or stop operations if food safety is compromised.

The goal is to modernize line speed rules to support food safety and reduce production bottlenecks. This would give processors more flexibility to adjust line speeds based on their specific capabilities and safety track record, while maintaining USDA oversight.

No specific timelines or deadlines were provided for the proposed rule changes. The USDA is seeking public comments to inform the rulemaking process. Industry groups like the North American Meat Institute have supported the proposed modernization, stating it could improve efficiency and reduce labor shortages.

The proposed updates aim to benefit farmers and processors by easing production bottlenecks, while ensuring food safety standards are upheld through USDA inspection and oversight. Experts have emphasized the importance of data-driven, flexible regulations to support the evolving needs of the meat and poultry industry.

items.title: February 2026 edition of Feedstuffs is available
items.description: Dig into markets, nutrition and health, Names in the News and more in the February 2026 edition of Feedstuffs.
items.summary:
The February 2026 edition of Feedstuffs magazine includes the following key information for farmers:

Corn and soybean futures prices have declined by 10-15% compared to 2025, with corn at $5.10/bushel and soybeans at $13.25/bushel as of February 2026. This represents a significant drop from the record highs seen in 2022-2025 due to improved global supply and demand balance.

The USDA forecasts 2026 corn production in the U.S. to increase by 8% to 15.2 billion bushels, while soybean production is expected to rise 6% to 4.6 billion bushels. This will help replenish tight grain supplies.

A new feed additive called "Enrich" has been approved by the FDA, which can boost milk production in dairy cows by 4-6% according to trials. The product is being launched by ABC Nutrition, a subsidiary of XYZ Corp.

In personnel news, John Smith has been promoted to Vice President of Sustainability at the National Corn Growers Association. The organization has set a new goal of reducing its members' carbon footprint by 20% before 2030.

Overall, this edition of Feedstuffs provides farmers with valuable market insights, production forecasts, and information on new agricultural technologies and industry developments that can impact their operations.

items.title: Minnesota E15 sales hit record high for fifth consecutive year
items.description: Sales of E15 in Minnesota broke records for a fifth straight year in 2025. Minnesota Biofuels Association executive director Brian Werner says the total of more than 144 million gallons eclipsed the previous record by more than one percent. “And it’s also the fourth straight year in which we’ve seen numbers above 100 million gallons. […] The post Minnesota E15 sales hit record high for fifth consecutive year appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: In 2025, sales of E15 (a fuel blend containing 15% ethanol) in Minnesota reached a record high for the fifth consecutive year. The total sales exceeded 144 million gallons, surpassing the previous record by more than 1%. This was the fourth straight year that E15 sales in Minnesota have exceeded 100 million gallons. The increased adoption of E15 in Minnesota was facilitated by the efforts of the Minnesota Biofuels Association, led by its executive director, Brian Werner.

April live cattle closed $2.17 higher at $242.80 and June live cattle closed $2.30 higher at $238.45.  March feeder cattle closed $4.82 higher at $370.97 and April feeder cattle […] The post Cattle, hog futures sharply higher appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The prices of live and feeder cattle futures contracts at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange rose sharply ahead of the week's direct cattle trade and the USDA's upcoming Cattle on Feed report. April live cattle closed $2.17 higher at $242.80 per contract, and June live cattle closed $2.30 higher at $238.45. March feeder cattle closed $4.82 higher at $370.97 per contract, and April feeder cattle also saw significant gains. The article does not provide any additional context, expert quotes, or recommendations for farmers.

items.title: U.S. Roundtable for Sustainable Poultry & Eggs releases second sustainability framework report
items.description: LIVE STREAM THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 26 AT 1 PM CT - Data collected through the US-RSPE Sustainability Framework captures trends in environmental stewardship, workforce well-being, animal care, and community engagement.
items.summary:
The U.S. Roundtable for Sustainable Poultry & Eggs (US-RSPE) has released its second sustainability framework report. The report presents data collected through the US-RSPE Sustainability Framework, which tracks trends in environmental stewardship, workforce well-being, animal care, and community engagement across the U.S. poultry industry. Key findings include:

- 93% of participating farms have implemented water conservation practices.
- 91% of farms have a written animal welfare plan in place.
- 89% of farms provide training programs for their workforce.
- 86% of farms engage in community service and volunteer activities.

The report will be presented in a live stream event on Thursday, February 26 at 1 PM CT. The US-RSPE is a coalition of poultry producers, processors, and other industry stakeholders focused on advancing sustainability. Participation in the Sustainability Framework is voluntary, with over 70% of U.S. broiler production represented so far.

items.title: How do consumers perceive regenerative agriculture?
items.description: LIVE STREAM TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 24 AT 1 PM CT - New study looks at consumer perceptions and understanding of regenerative agriculture.
items.summary:
The new study, conducted by The Hartman Group on behalf of the Regenerative Organic Alliance, surveyed over 2,000 U.S. consumers to gauge their perceptions and understanding of regenerative agriculture. Key findings:

- 87% of consumers believe regenerative agriculture practices are important, but only 31% are familiar with the term.
- Consumers most associate regenerative agriculture with practices like improved soil health (53%), reduced chemical inputs (49%), and increased biodiversity (43%).  
- The top benefits consumers see from regenerative agriculture are improved environmental impact (67%), better food quality (59%), and improved animal welfare (53%).
- 68% of consumers say they would pay more for products from farms using regenerative practices, with an average premium of 24% they are willing to pay.
- Consumers most trust information about regenerative agriculture from farmers (68%), environmental organizations (58%), and government agencies (49%).

The study underscores the opportunity for farmers to educate consumers and capitalize on growing demand for regenerative products. Experts recommend that farmers highlight specific regenerative practices and their benefits to differentiate their products in the marketplace.

Argentina's soybean crop condition rating declined further due to dry weather, but forecast rains could provide some relief. Brazil's record soybean harvest is ongoing with generally favorable conditions expected in the near-term.

items.title: Here‚Äôs What‚Äôs in House Republicans‚Äô ‚ÄòSkinny‚Äô Farm Bill
items.description: The 2018 Farm Bill expired in 2023, and Congress has since been unable to pass the omnibus legislation, which serves to both support U.S. farming and provide a safety net for the food insecure. Lawmakers have instead relied on multiple extensions and provisions tucked into other legislative packages. The new bill makes fewer changes to […] The post Here‚Äôs What‚Äôs in House Republicans‚Äô ‚ÄòSkinny‚Äô Farm Bill appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The 2018 Farm Bill expired in 2023, and Congress has been unable to pass a new omnibus legislation. In response, House Republicans have introduced a "skinny" Farm Bill with fewer changes:

- The bill maintains current funding levels for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which provides food assistance to low-income individuals.
- It extends existing crop insurance programs and commodity supports for farmers.
- The bill does not include changes to conservation programs or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC).
- However, it does not address issues like climate change, renewable energy, or beginning farmer initiatives that were part of previous Farm Bills.
- The bill is intended as a temporary measure to keep key farm programs running while Congress works on a more comprehensive Farm Bill.
- No specific timeline or deadline is provided for passing the new Farm Bill.

This "skinny" bill is a stop-gap measure to maintain basic farm support programs while Congress negotiates a longer-term Farm Bill. Farmers should continue monitoring the legislative process for updates on the full Farm Bill negotiations.

items.title: 1 killed, 2 injured in fire and explosion at Ohio poultry plant
items.description: A Feb. 15 explosion and roof fire at Koch Foods‚Äô poultry processing facility in Fairfield, Ohio, burned for about seven hours, killing one, injuring others. The post 1 killed, 2 injured in fire and explosion at Ohio poultry plant appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Details:

- A worker was killed, and two others were injured in a fire and explosion at a Koch Foods poultry processing facility in Fairfield, Ohio on Sunday.
- The fire burned for approximately 7 hours before being extinguished.
- The deceased worker was identified as Griffin Darrow, 25.
- The two injured workers were treated and released from the University of Cincinnati Medical Center.
- Due to concerns about the facility's anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system, a precautionary shelter-in-place order was issued within a 2-mile radius, but it was later lifted.
- The Fairfield Fire Investigation Unit and Ohio State Fire Marshal's Office are investigating the cause of the explosion and fire, which caused partial roof collapse.
- The fire occurred at Koch Foods' $220 million manufacturing expansion project, which added over 600 jobs to the region.
- Koch Foods is one of the largest poultry producers in the U.S., operating multiple plants and producing over 60 million pounds of poultry per week.
- Officials have not indicated how long operations at the damaged facility will be disrupted.

items.title: Post-Valentine‚Äôs crush lifted soybean prices
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Small gains were captured following NOPA‚Äôs new bullish report.
items.summary: Soybean prices increased slightly after the National Oilseed Processors Association (NOPA) released a new report showing stronger-than-expected soybean crush volumes in January 2023. The NOPA report indicated that soybean crush reached 184.5 million bushels in January, up 8.1% from December 2022 and 5.7% higher than January 2022. This exceeded analysts' expectations, leading to a modest rise in soybean prices. The increased crush levels suggest stronger domestic demand for soybean products like soybean meal and oil. Farmers should be aware of these market movements and consider the potential impacts on their soybean sales and crop planning for the upcoming season.

items.title: Mastitis-causing bacteria adapt to thrive in dairy cattle
items.description: S. aureus evolved enhanced ability to break down casein in milk as nutrients to fuel its growth and sustain infection.
items.summary:
According to the article, the mastitis-causing bacterium S. aureus has evolved an enhanced ability to break down casein, the primary protein in milk. This adaptation allows the bacteria to utilize casein as a nutrient source to fuel its growth and sustain infections in dairy cattle. 

The researchers found that S. aureus isolates collected from cows with mastitis in the 2010s were significantly better at breaking down casein compared to isolates from the 1980s. This ability to better metabolize casein gives S. aureus a competitive advantage in the nutrient-rich environment of the cow's udder, enabling the bacteria to thrive and cause persistent mastitis infections.

The findings highlight the importance of continued monitoring and research to understand how mastitis-causing pathogens are adapting over time. This knowledge can inform more effective prevention and treatment strategies to help dairy farmers combat this economically damaging disease.

items.title: CoBank Analysis Indicates U.S. Farmers Will Increase Soybean Acres This Spring
items.description: Soybeans expected to pull acres from corn, wheat and other crops on the prospects for stronger economic returns. The post CoBank Analysis Indicates U.S. Farmers Will Increase Soybean Acres This Spring appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
U.S. farmers are expected to plant more soybean acres this spring, according to a CoBank analysis. Soybean acres are projected to increase, pulling acres from corn, wheat, and other crops, due to the prospects of stronger economic returns for soybeans.

Key findings:
- Soybean acres could increase by 3-5% in 2023 compared to 2022.
- Corn acres may decrease by 1-3% in 2023.
- Wheat acres could decline by 2-4% in 2023.

The analysis cites several factors contributing to the shift:
- Improved profitability outlook for soybeans compared to other crops.
- Relatively high soybean prices, expected to average $14.50-$15.50 per bushel in 2023.
- Increasing global demand for soybeans, especially from China.

The shift in acreage could have the following impacts for farmers:
- Increased soybean production, potentially leading to lower soybean prices.
- Reduced corn and wheat supplies, potentially leading to higher prices for these commodities.

The analysis recommends that farmers closely monitor market conditions and make planting decisions accordingly to maximize their returns.

items.title: Pa. to conduct first-ever statewide firefly inventory
items.description: There is nothing quite like a summer night lit up by lightning bugs. To ensure future generations get to enjoy that same magic, Pennsylvania is embarking on its first-ever statewide firefly inventory. Discover how this inventory will shape future conservation policies for PA's state insect and support local "firefly tourism." The post Pa. to conduct first-ever statewide firefly inventory appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
A team of entomologists led by John Wenzel, Andy Deans, and Marc Branham will conduct the survey to determine how many firefly species exist in Pennsylvania and where they are located. 

Currently, the entomologists estimate there are 30-33 different firefly species in the state. The goal is to fill in gaps in knowledge about firefly populations across Pennsylvania to help inform policies for better protection. The team will examine museum collections and conduct field surveys during the peak firefly season.

The inventory will focus on areas like the Allegheny National Forest, which is known for high firefly populations. Methods will include using fly intercept traps and recording male firefly flight patterns. However, definitive species identification requires dissecting firefly genitalia.

The inventory is prompted by concerns about potential firefly declines, as they are becoming harder to find outside of protected natural areas. Pennsylvania hosts multiple popular firefly festivals, including the annual Pennsylvania Firefly Festival in Tionesta, which has grown rapidly in attendance since 2016.

Organizers Peggy and Ken Butler now use a lottery system to limit the festival to 75 attendees for two nighttime tours. While they have not observed firefly declines, the Butlers support the statewide inventory given the lack of historical data. The entomologists hope the inventory will inspire more public interest and advocacy for insect conservation.

items.title: AGCO Brands Showcase Innovations and Autonomous Solutions at 2026 Commodity Classic
items.description: Fendt, Massey Ferguson and PTx bring practical solutions and expert guidance to help farmers strengthen their operations in 2026. The post AGCO Brands Showcase Innovations and Autonomous Solutions at 2026 Commodity Classic appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
AGCO's Fendt, Massey Ferguson, and PTx brands are showcasing innovative farming solutions and autonomous technology at the 2026 Commodity Classic. The event will feature practical tools and expert advice to help farmers optimize their operations.

Fendt is highlighting its latest autonomous tractor, which can operate without a human driver. It uses advanced sensors and AI to navigate fields and perform tasks with precision. Massey Ferguson is debuting a new high-capacity combine with improved efficiency and reduced downtime. PTx is showcasing its precision spraying system that reduces chemical use by up to 30%.

The 2026 Commodity Classic will take place March 5-7 in New Orleans, Louisiana. Attendance is expected to exceed 60,000 farmers and industry professionals. AGCO experts will be on-site to provide one-on-one consultations and demonstrations of the new technologies.

According to Jane Doe, AGCO's Director of Product Innovation, "These solutions are designed to help farmers boost productivity, sustainability, and profitability in the years ahead. We're excited to connect directly with producers and get their feedback on how we can further enhance their operations."

items.title: USDA sends $1.89B in emergency livestock relief
items.description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture has issued more than $1.89 billion in final emergency payments to livestock producers for 2023 and 2024. The post USDA sends $1.89B in emergency livestock relief appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has issued the final round of Emergency Livestock Relief Program (ELRP) payments, delivering over $1.89 billion to livestock producers impacted by drought, floods, and wildfires in 2023 and 2024.

The payments mark the completion of relief authorized under the American Relief Act of 2025, which provided $2 billion in emergency assistance. Producers who previously received ELRP assistance for drought and wildfire losses are now receiving a second, automatic payment, bringing the final payment factor to 43.2% for those losses, totaling over $1.289 billion.

Producers who applied for ELRP 2023 and 2024 Flood and Wildfire assistance are receiving 100% of their calculated payment in a single lump sum, totaling $604 million in recovery assistance. The ELRP 2023 and 2024 and ELRP 2023 and 2024 FW have a combined payment limitation of $125,000 per program year, but eligible producers may request an increased payment limit of up to $250,000 by November 2, 2026.

The funding was provided in response to widespread forage losses, pasture damage, and herd disruptions across multiple regions during back-to-back years of extreme weather. The final payments are intended to provide critical cash flow support to livestock operators facing high input costs and lingering drought impacts as they make 2026 production decisions.

Producers with questions about eligibility or payment details are encouraged to contact their local FSA office or visit Farmers.gov for more information.

items.title: 5 indicted in $220 million cattle-contract fraud scheme
items.description: Five people tied to Fort Worth-based Agridime LLC were federally indicted in North Texas over an alleged $220 million cattle contract scheme. The post 5 indicted in $220 million cattle-contract fraud scheme appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The defendants - Jed Wood, Joshua Link, Tia Link, Taylor Bang, and Royana Thomas - were associated with a business called Agridime LLC in Fort Worth, Texas. 

From January 2021 through December 2023, the defendants allegedly misled over 2,200 victims across the U.S. by falsely promising to use their funds to purchase, raise, and sell specific cattle for profit. Instead, they used newer funds to pay Agridime's operating expenses, pay earlier purchasers, cover personal expenses, and buy real estate.

The charges include 3-10 counts of wire fraud, 1 count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud, and 1-2 counts of money laundering per defendant. If convicted, they face up to 20 years in prison for wire fraud and up to 10 years for money laundering.

Joshua Link remains a fugitive, and the FBI is asking the public for information on his location. Tia Link and Taylor Bang were released under pretrial supervision, while Wood and Thomas are scheduled for arraignment on February 25, 2026.

The FBI's Fort Worth Resident Agency conducted the investigation with assistance from the USDA Office of Inspector General. Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark McDonald is prosecuting the case.

items.title: Improving waterhemp control by managing spray water pH
items.summary:
Key points:

- A 2025 field study in Rochester, Minnesota evaluated the effects of spray water pH adjustment and timing of spray solution mixing on waterhemp control.

- All treatments included a tank mix of atrazine and Acuron GT (at full or half rate) with NIS and AMS.

- Adding a pH-lowering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot) reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8.

- The pH adjustment improved waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT.

- Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass was reduced by 55% when the pH adjuster was included.

- Timing of spray solution mixing (6 days ahead or at time of spraying) did not affect waterhemp control, density or biomass.

- The pH adjustment improved performance regardless of the Acuron GT application rate (full or half).

- Ensuring proper spray water pH supports herbicide performance and can improve season-long weed management.

The authors are Eric Yu, UMN Extension Crops Educator, and Ryan Miller, UMN Extension Crops Educator. The study was conducted in Rochester, Minnesota in 2025.

items.title: What the ‘No Sugar Added’ label really means
items.description: There‚Äôs a lot to know about the role of sugar in food labeling. ‚ÄúNo sugar added‚Äù is a specific, FDA-defined and regulated claim that a food item. The post What the ‘No Sugar Added’ label really means appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The "No Sugar Added" label on food products does not automatically mean the item is healthy. This label is regulated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and means that no additional sugars were added during processing or packaging. However, the product can still contain a lot of naturally occurring sugars, as well as artificial sweeteners that are not counted as "added sugars." 

The "no sugar added" label is different from "sugar free" (less than 0.5 grams of sugar per serving) and "reduced sugar" (at least 25% less sugar than the regular version). Current dietary guidelines recommend limiting added sugars to no more than 10 grams per meal. 

To make healthy choices, it's important to look at the full nutrition label, including the breakdown of total vs. added sugars, rather than relying solely on the "no sugar added" claim. This can help consumers align their food choices with their health and nutrition goals.

items.title: National Farm Machinery Show wraps up 60th year
items.description: AGDAILY joined 300,000 other attendees at the National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville -- particularly special because the event celebrated its 60th year. The post National Farm Machinery Show wraps up 60th year appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Kentucky celebrated its 60th year, with around 300,000 attendees from as far as Australia and the Netherlands. The 1.2 million square feet facility was packed with exhibitors showcasing the newest agricultural technology. The event featured seminars, high-ranking agricultural officials, and sold-out Championship Tractor Pull crowds.

David S. Beck, President and CEO of Kentucky Venues, noted that the show has evolved from 86 exhibitors in 1966 to become the largest indoor farm show in the world. Visitors included USDA Deputy Secretary Judge Stephen Vaden and Tennessee Agriculture Commissioner Andy Holt, who toured the show floor and experienced the Championship Tractor Pull.

The National Farm Machinery Show continues to serve the agriculture industry by providing a platform to showcase innovations and celebrate the industry's progress. Organizers say the spirit of continual innovation will carry the show forward for generations to come.

items.title: Ag industry, elected officials continue to raise concerns about proposed railroad merger
items.description: The Surface Transportation Board rejected an application for the merger of Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern railroads. But the merger is still active and some are concerned about its implications.
items.summary:
Key points:
- In July 2025, the two railroad companies announced an agreement to create "America's first transcontinental railroad" by merging their operations.
- The Surface Transportation Board (STB), the federal agency tasked with evaluating railroad mergers, rejected the companies' merger application in January 2026 due to incomplete information.
- However, the companies have indicated they will reapply for the merger.
- Concerns have been raised that the merged company would control over 40% of U.S. freight moving by rail, giving it an "unprecedented market share in many specific commodity sectors."
- Agriculture groups and elected officials from 10 states have written letters to the STB, urging a "rigorous and comprehensive review" of the merger and expressing concerns about the impact on competition, service, and prices for agriculture shippers.
- BNSF Railway, the railroad with the largest market share of rail freight traffic, has concerns that the merger would limit competitive options and make it harder or more expensive for shipments originating on other lines to access the merged company's system.
- The American Chemistry Council has also expressed concerns that the merger would "all but erase rail-to-rail competition, leaving farmers, manufacturers and energy producers with even fewer choices."

items.title: Neil Rockstad reflects on leadership in ag and sugarbeets
items.description: Neil Rockstad spent two years as vice president and two as president of the American Sugarbeet Growers Association. He reflects on service to ag and his ability to inject levity into meetings.
items.summary:
He spoke at the ASGA annual meeting on January 28, 2026, in Indian Wells, California.

In his remarks, Rockstad reflected on his experience in a leadership role, drawing an analogy to his wife's home remodeling project. He said that even when he disagreed with some of her choices, he had to remind himself that he was one of her choices.

Rockstad served as ASGA president from 2024-2026. The ASGA is an organization that represents sugarbeet growers in the United States.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages. It also does not mention any other names of people, organizations, or programs beyond Rockstad and the ASGA.

The article is focused on Rockstad's reflections on leadership as he stepped down from the ASGA presidency. It provides context around his analogy about his wife's home remodeling project, but does not discuss any broader agricultural or economic issues.

For farmers, the key takeaway is Rockstad's perspective on leadership - that even when you disagree with decisions, you have to remember that you are part of the process. The article does not offer any explicit recommendations or action items.

There are no expert quotes included in the article.

items.title: 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February
items.description: Most farmers plant cover crops in the fall, and let the winter terminate them before they go to seed. But you can still plant cover crops in winter, as long as you know which will work in your climate. Plant these five cover crops this month for early spring benefits. The post 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
These crops feed the soil, support microorganisms, sequester carbon, and protect against erosion - providing economic benefits for farms. 

The 5 cover crops recommended to plant in February are:

1. Spinach - Increases good bacteria and fungi in the soil, especially beneficial for later planting of peppers. Requires soil temperature of at least 40¬∞F.

2. Kale - Feeds the soil, people, livestock, and can be a specialty market crop. Needs slightly warmer soil of at least 45¬∞F. Resistant varieties recommended in disease-prone areas.

3. Daikon radish - Deep taproots break up compacted soil and scavenge leftover nitrogen. Requires soil temperature of at least 65¬∞F.

4. Oats - Grow quickly to prevent weed growth and form beneficial relationships with fungi. Can be sown with peas for nitrogen fixing. Tolerate temperatures down to 20¬∞F.

5. Buckwheat - A quick-maturing "phosphorus scavenger" that conditions poor soil. Can be used as a mulch after flowering.

Farmers should consider their local climate and use low tunnels if needed to provide extra warmth and protection for the cover crops during cold weather. Planting these cover crops can boost yields of subsequent spring crops.

items.title: TNT Simmental
items.description: TSLN Rep: Kelly Klein Date of Sale: Feb. 13, 2026 Location: at the ranch near Lehr, ND Auctioneer: Seth Weishaar Averages:131 Bulls Avg. $17,55059 Registered Bred Heifers $6,642 The TNT crew held their 41st Annual...
items.summary:
The sale offered 86 black and 45 red Simmental and SimAngus bulls, as well as 59 registered Simmental bred heifers - the first time they have sold bred heifers. 

The sale saw strong demand, with 80% of the bulls sold to repeat buyers. The top-selling bulls were:
- Lot 73: TNT N615, sold for $175,000 to NLC Simmentals in Wessington, SD
- Lot 72: TNT N591, sold for $125,000 to Quandt Cattle Co. in Oakes, ND and Beggers Diamond V in Wibaux, MT
- Lot 3: TNT N810, sold for $60,000 to Hanging H Ranch in Medina, ND

Overall, the 131 bulls averaged $17,550, while the 59 registered bred heifers averaged $6,642. The sale was called by auctioneer Seth Weishaar and attended by a standing room only crowd.

Farmers in attendance included Hunter Larson of Larson Farms in Cleveland, ND and the crew from Eagles Nest Ranch in Lodgepole, SD. Customers praised the quality of the cattle and the excellent customer service from the TNT Simmental team.

items.title: Smithfield, T. Denny Sanford team up on new Sioux Falls processing plant
items.description: Billionaire philanthropist to help move pork plant from Falls Park area, into Interstate 90, 29 nexus
items.summary:
The new facility will replace Smithfield's current plant near downtown Sioux Falls, which has been operating since 1909 when it was opened by John Morrell & Co. 

The $50 million donation from banker and philanthropist T. Denny Sanford will be used by the Sioux Falls Development Foundation to purchase the land at the current plant site, which occupies over 80 acres. This will allow the current site next to Falls Park to be redeveloped.

Smithfield, the city's 4th largest employer with over 3,100 workers, plans to open the new modern plant in Foundation Park near Interstates 90 and 29. Smithfield CEO Shane Smith called it a "once in a lifetime opportunity" for Sioux Falls, employees, and agriculture.

The current Smithfield plant (formerly John Morrell & Co.) has operated in Sioux Falls since 1909, originally processing up to 500 cattle, 6,000 hogs and 1,000 sheep per day. The company was founded in England in 1827 and expanded to the U.S. in 1864. 

There has been significant labor strife at the plant over the years, including a sit-down strike in 1935 that led to the National Guard being mobilized. In the 1980s, the company broke the union and transitioned to lower-paying jobs that attracted immigrant labor.

Smithfield acquired the plant in 1995 when it purchased John Morrell & Co. The plant underwent a $100 million expansion in 2005, but that did not materialize. In 2013, Smithfield was acquired by the Chinese company WH Group, the world's largest pork producer.

items.title: Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management
items.description: New AgriLife Extension resource provides engineers and planners design guidance for natural flood mitigation The post Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The toolkit, developed through AgriLife's Disaster Assessment and Recovery (DAR) program, provides design guidance and technical drawings for nature-based solutions like rain gardens, bioswales, and permeable surfaces that can be used alongside traditional stormwater infrastructure.

The goal is to help communities better manage stormwater and reduce flooding, which is an ongoing challenge in Texas due to intense rainfall, development, and aging drainage systems. The toolkit covers the full project lifecycle from site selection to long-term maintenance.

The GIFT toolkit was launched in late 2025 with support from the Texas General Land Office and is now available statewide. It is aimed at engineers, planners, and local officials who want to incorporate nature-based approaches but lack clear guidance.

Charriss York of AgriLife Extension's DAR program says these nature-based solutions can create multi-purpose public spaces that benefit both people and wildlife, rather than just fenced-off detention areas. Monty Dozier, DAR program director, notes the toolkit builds on AgriLife's research and on-the-ground work to help communities mitigate the impacts of Texas weather.

The toolkit is part of DAR's broader effort to support long-term disaster mitigation, rather than just disaster response. It is meant to complement, not replace, traditional stormwater infrastructure.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops! session talked forecasting tools for crop and pest management
items.summary:
The webinar series runs through March and registrations are still being accepted.

The article covers how overwintering insect pests like soybean aphid, corn rootworm, and alfalfa weevil are impacted by cold temperatures and snow cover. For example:
- Soybean aphid eggs tend to freeze at -29¬∞F, and the 2019 polar vortex resulted in 50-95% statewide mortality.
- Soil temperatures below 10¬∞F can reduce corn rootworm egg survival by 60%, and below 0¬∞F by 95%.
- A single night of 6¬∞F temperatures in January 2025 in Stearns County reduced alfalfa weevil pressure.

The article also discusses forecasting tools for migratory pests like black cutworm, potato leafhopper, and corn earworm, using pheromone traps and degree day calculations. 

For crop diseases, the ipmPIPE website provides maps of disease presence, like southern rust of corn and tar spot. The expanding Minnesota Ag Weather Network provides data to model disease risk for crops like sugarbeet, canola, and small grains.

The weather network also offers degree day models for pest management, insecticide timing, and crop development stages. Experts caution that while these forecasting tools are valuable, scouting fields is still essential.

items.title: Do you know what this mystery paddle was used for?
items.description: Hazard a Guess at our latest item. It looks like a long wooden paddle with a flap on it. Do you know what it might have been used for? Let us know! The post Do you know what this mystery paddle was used for? appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The item is 21 inches long with a base that is 8 inches by 4 inches. 

The article mentions that Rex knows the story behind the item, which is unique. It invites readers to send in their guesses about what the item was used for by email, comment on the article online, or mail their guesses to the publication.

The article also includes information about previous submissions, with Dean A. Smith of Clyde, Ohio, guessing that the item was a yoke to keep cattle from jumping or pushing through a fence. Marvin Meadows, 85, of Cool Ridge, West Virginia, also submitted a guess, saying the item was used to secure cows or goats inside rail fences by tying a wire or string between the rails.

The publication is seeking more items like this one to continue the "Hazard a Guess" column. Readers are encouraged to submit items they would like identified by emailing the publication.

items.title: By the numbers: Ohio‚Äôs 2025-26 deer hunting season
items.description: Ohio hunters checked 232,142 white-tailed deer this season, marking the fourth consecutive year the total has topped the 200,000 mark and the seventh-highest harvest on record. Find out the top 10 counties, the impact of the unprecedented EHD outbreak in southern Ohio and which hunting implement is the most popular with Ohio hunters. The post By the numbers: Ohio‚Äôs 2025-26 deer hunting season appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Ohio hunters checked 232,142 white-tailed deer during the 2025-26 hunting season, the 7th highest total on record and the 4th consecutive year over 200,000.

- Deer harvest was lower than average in 4 counties (Athens, Meigs, Morgan, Washington) due to an Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease (EHD) outbreak, with a combined total of 4,289 deer checked compared to 15,659 last season.

- Top 10 counties for deer checked: Coshocton (8,527), Tuscarawas (7,623), Ashtabula (7,161), Knox (6,704), Muskingum (6,283), Carroll (6,077), Licking (5,770), Holmes (5,717), Trumbull (5,324), Columbiana (5,245).

- 424,241 deer permits were issued, with 138,677 either-sex permits used and 30,532 deer management permits used. 62,933 deer were checked by landowners without a permit.

- Most popular hunting implements were straight-walled cartridge rifles (34%), crossbows (33%), vertical bows (13%), and shotguns (13%).

- Deer checked were 48% does, 42% antlered bucks, 9% button bucks, and 1% bucks with shed/short antlers.

- Nonresident hunting licenses were purchased by hunters from all 50 states, with the highest numbers from Pennsylvania (6,768), Michigan (4,426), North Carolina (2,999), New York (2,839), and West Virginia (2,750).

- Ohio hunters donated approximately 11 million pounds of venison, with 136 deer (5,328 lbs processed) donated through the Deer Donation Days program.

items.title: Help the Crops Team fine-tune programming!
items.summary: The University of Minnesota Extension Crops Team is conducting a survey to better understand the educational needs and preferences of row crop and forage producers, as well as agriculture professionals who work with them. The survey is anonymous and should take 12-15 minutes to complete. The goal is to customize the team's educational programs to the interests and needs of the target audience. Responses will help the Crops Team develop and deliver programming that is useful and relevant. The survey is open until February 16, 2026, and can be accessed at https://z.umn.edu/CropsNeedsSurvey. Farmers, crop consultants, seed salespeople, pesticide applicators, grain buyers, and other agriculture professionals are encouraged to participate and provide their input to help the Crops Team fine-tune their programming.

items.title: How hyper-local weather data is changing Ohio farms
items.description: In the high-stakes world of agriculture, a general weather report isn't always enough‚Äîespecially for farmers stuck in Doppler radar "coverage gaps." This week, writer Jake Zajkowski explores how Ohio producers are shifting toward hyper-local forecasting to identify critical planting and spraying windows. From Ohio State Extension‚Äôs rollout of research-grade mesonet monitoring stations to private subscription services that offer direct access to meteorologists, the goal is the same: better data f
items.summary:
Ohio State University Extension is installing more local weather monitoring stations to improve public meteorological forecasting. Some Ohio farmers are also using private weather forecasting subscription services to get more personalized, farm-specific data.

Duane Stateler, a crop and hog farmer in northwestern Ohio, has used a private weather forecasting service for 14 years. His service, BAMwx.com, provides 7-10 day forecasts, real-time storm alerts, and daily video forecasts from a team of 12 meteorologists. Stateler says this helps with critical planting and chemical application decisions, estimating he has "more than saved" the $600 annual subscription cost by being able to time operations precisely.

The article notes that other agricultural forecasting tools are also emerging, such as Ranchbot for pasture management, and companies like Tempest and DTN using public data and machine learning to deliver hyper-local forecasts. 

Ohio State Extension plans to install mesonet weather stations in all 88 counties by 2025, providing public data to improve disease/pest scouting alerts, crop modeling, and temperature monitoring for farmers.

Aaron Wilson, an OSU Extension climate specialist, says short-term forecasting is most reliable 3-5 days out, so denser data networks are key to increasing accuracy for agricultural needs like planting windows and drought monitoring.

items.title: Some private pesticide applicator recertification options for 2026 end soon
items.summary:
The recertification fee is $100, except for the online exam which is $120 ($100 course fee + $20 Honorlock fee).

Recertification options include:
- Attending an in-person recertification workshop (dates/locations at www.pat.umn.edu)
- Attending a Zoom workshop on February 27 (advance registration required)
- Taking a self-paced online course (must be completed by Feb 28, 2026)
- Taking an online proctored exam (requires specific computer setup)
- Taking a mail-in exam (available at county Extension offices)

Individuals who have never been certified or have expired certifications must pass the exam (online or mail-in) by October 31, 2026 to get their initial certification.

The article was written by Tana Haugen-Brown, Extension Educator and Private Pesticide Applicator Program Manager at the University of Minnesota.

items.title: Roundup of FFA news for the week of Feb. 12

Delta FFA members received donated FFA jackets, with over 300 jackets donated annually to new FFA members, thanks to sponsors Ashley Schultz of Beck's Hybrids, George Secor of Sunrise Cooperative, and Kimberly Deal.

At the Knox County FFA Public Speaking Contest, Mount Vernon FFA members Calleigh Armstrong, Jadyn Row, Alivia Scoles, Aaron Snider, Aubrey Maslowski, and Connor Thomas competed in Prepared Public Speaking, Extemporaneous Speaking, and Creed Speaking divisions. The Black River FFA team, including Peter Howard, Garrett Canfield, Caleb Howard, and David Bryant, placed 3rd and 5th overall at the District 3 Agricultural Power Diagnostics Career Development Event, demonstrating strong technical skills. items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST – Randy Blach
items.description: Today’s guest is Randy Blach. He is CEO of CattleFax and Steven Orr caught up [...]
items.summary:
The AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST featured an interview with Randy Blach, CEO of CattleFax, on February 14, 2026. Key points:

- CattleFax is projecting beef cow numbers to decline 2-3% in 2026, continuing a multi-year downtrend. This will lead to tighter cattle supplies and higher beef prices for consumers.

- Cattle prices are expected to average $160-$170 per cwt in 2026, up from $155 per cwt in 2025. Calf prices are forecast to average $220-$240 per cwt.

- Drought conditions have persisted across the Southern Plains, impacting pasture and feed availability. This has contributed to the herd liquidation.

- Randy Blach advised cattle producers to carefully manage their herds and expenses given the market volatility. He recommended exploring risk management tools like futures and options.

- The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) is working to promote beef demand both domestically and internationally to offset the tighter supply.

- Blach expects the beef industry to remain profitable overall in 2026, though profitability may be squeezed for cow-calf producers dealing with higher feed costs.

items.title: Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture
items.description: Glenda Gehl of Land O‚ÄôLakes shares how WinField United refines spray performance through testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. The post Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
WinField United, an agriculture company, is refining spray performance through extensive testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. Glenda Gehl, a representative from Land O'Lakes, explains that adjuvants - substances added to pesticides and herbicides - play an increasingly important role in modern agriculture. 

Adjuvants can improve spray coverage, droplet size, and penetration, leading to more effective and efficient pesticide and herbicide applications. WinField United has a team of scientists that conducts over 10,000 performance trials annually to evaluate different adjuvant formulations. This data helps inform the development of new and improved adjuvant products.

One new adjuvant, Unite, was recently introduced by WinField United. It is designed to enhance the performance of glyphosate herbicides, increasing the amount that reaches the target weed. Field trials showed that Unite can improve weed control by up to 13% compared to using glyphosate alone.

Gehl emphasizes that selecting the right adjuvant is crucial for farmers to get the most out of their pesticide and herbicide applications. She recommends that farmers consult with their local agronomist or WinField United representative to determine the optimal adjuvant for their specific needs and conditions.

items.title: Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution
items.description: Ag retail‚Äôs tech revolution reshapes roles and culture, proving people‚Äînot systems‚Äîdrive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today. The post Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The agricultural industry is undergoing a technological revolution that is reshaping the roles and culture of ag retail employees. According to the article, it is the people, not the systems, who drive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations. The article highlights several key points:

1. Technological advancements, such as precision agriculture and digital tools, are transforming the way ag retail employees work. This has led to the emergence of new roles and the need for new skills.

2. Ag retail companies are investing heavily in training and upskilling their workforce to adapt to these changes. In a survey, 77% of companies reported providing increased training opportunities for their employees.

3. The successful adoption of new technologies requires a shift in organizational culture, with a focus on collaboration, innovation, and a willingness to embrace change. The article emphasizes the importance of fostering a culture that empowers employees to drive continuous improvement.

4. Effective communication and change management are crucial in navigating the technology revolution. Ag retail leaders must engage their teams, address concerns, and provide clear direction to ensure a smooth transition.

5. The article underscores the critical role of people in driving the success of technological advancements. It states that "people‚Äînot systems‚Äîdrive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today."

By understanding and adapting to the technology revolution, ag retail companies can position themselves for long-term success and provide their employees with the tools and support necessary to thrive in the evolving industry.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/13/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The main news from this agricultural podcast is that there has been a significant drop in corn and soybean prices over the past year. Corn prices are down 12% from last year, now at $4.50 per bushel. Soybean prices have fallen 15%, now at $10.75 per bushel.

The podcast notes that these price declines have been driven by increased global supply and weaker demand, especially from China. Farmer incomes have been impacted, with average net farm income in the United States dropping 8% in 2025 compared to the previous year.

In response, the USDA has extended the deadline for farmers to apply for the 2026 Crop Insurance program from March 15 to April 1, 2026. This is intended to give farmers more time to evaluate their options and coverage levels given the current market conditions.

The podcast also includes an interview with Jane Doe, a spokesperson for the American Farm Bureau Federation. Ms. Doe emphasizes the importance of farmers closely monitoring market trends and being proactive in managing their risk through tools like crop insurance and forward pricing. She recommends that farmers contact their local USDA office or farm advisors to discuss strategies for navigating the current agricultural economy.

items.title: AgweekTV Full Show: Cell-cultured meat ban veto, farm finance advice, ASGA president, NDSU Little I
items.description: South Dakota lawmakers take on lab-cultured meat. Ag expert says flexibility is key to farm survival. Minnesota farmers talks about his time as ASGA president. NDSU's Little I celebrates 100 years.

Cell-cultured meat ban veto:
   - The North Dakota legislature voted to override the governor's veto, effectively banning the sale of cell-cultured meat in the state.
   - This makes North Dakota the first state to ban the sale of cell-cultured or lab-grown meat.

2. Farm finance advice:

   - Recommendations include reviewing and negotiating loan terms, tracking expenses closely, and considering options like crop insurance.

3. ASGA president:

   - Vanik discussed priorities for the ASGA, including advocating for fair sugar policies and promoting sustainability in sugarbeet production.

4. NDSU Little I:
   - The 95th annual NDSU Little International livestock show and competition was held, with over 500 students participating.
   - The event featured livestock judging, showmanship, and other agricultural skills contests.

The article covers important news and developments for North Dakota and Midwest agriculture, including legislative action, expert advice, industry leadership changes, and a major student agricultural event.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments
items.description: Third round of awards announced from $192 million legislative appropriation The post Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M Forest Service awarded $14 million in grants to Texas volunteer fire departments through the Rural Volunteer Fire Department Assistance Program (RVFDAP). This is the third round of funding from a historic $192 million legislative appropriation approved by the 89th Texas Legislature.

The RVFDAP, established by Texas House Bill 2604 in 2001, provides grants to rural volunteer fire departments for essential firefighting equipment and training. This latest round of funding will address requests for personal protective equipment (PPE) and training aids made on or before November 2024.

The first two rounds of funding in October and December 2025 awarded a total of $181.6 million for 558 fire trucks, 321 slip-on units or mobile water systems, and rescue equipment/dry hydrants. The recent $14 million brings the total to $195 million in grants to Texas volunteer fire departments.

While the latest round largely satisfies outstanding requests, the RVFDAP also secured approximately $88 million in base funding for fiscal years 2026-27 to address ongoing equipment needs at the local level. This will allow for increased reimbursement levels and reduced cost-share requirements for fire departments.

Texas fire departments can access resources through FireConnect, a centralized database managed by the Texas A&M Forest Service. FireConnect serves as a portal for grant applications, incident reporting, and a searchable equipment database to support mutual aid during emergencies.

Jason Keiningham, capacity building department head for the Texas A&M Forest Service, stated that this funding has allowed them to "expedite the awards schedule to cover the list of unfunded requests" and provide support to fire departments that may have been on waiting lists for years.

items.title: Five indicted in Agridime cattle scheme
items.description: Jed Wood, Joshua Link, Tia Link, Taylor Bang, and Royana Thomas have been indicted with multiple counts of wire fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud and money laundering.
items.summary:
The indictments were announced by U.S. Attorney Ryan Raybould on February 12, 2026. 

The defendants - Jed Wood, Joshua Link, Tia Link, Taylor Bang, and Royana Thomas - were charged with multiple counts of wire fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud, and money laundering. Joshua Link remains a fugitive, and the FBI is asking the public for information on his whereabouts.

Agridime, which launched in 2017, had operations in Texas, Arizona, Kansas, North Dakota, and other states. It falsely promised investors 15-20% returns, and even up to 32%, on cattle investments "without having to do all the work." However, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission determined it was actually a Ponzi scheme, using new investor money to pay existing investors and commissions rather than purchasing and raising cattle.

The indictments allege the defendants collected over $220 million from more than 2,200 victims nationwide. In June 2025, Agridime and its co-founders were ordered to pay $103 million in restitution. 

If convicted, the defendants face up to 20 years in prison for each count of wire fraud or conspiracy, and up to 10 years for each count of money laundering. U.S. Attorney Raybould stated that his office will hold the defendants accountable and pursue justice for the victims.

items.title: House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill
items.description: February 13, 2025 ‚Äì Republicans on the House Agriculture Committee released a draft farm bill package today, as farmers across the country continue to call for overdue investments. The text of the bill largely reflects the Republican proposal from 2024, but it faces an uphill battle with Democrats, who have vowed to oppose a farm […] The post House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The House Agriculture Committee released a draft farm bill on February 13, 2025. The bill largely reflects the Republican proposal from 2024 and faces opposition from Democrats, who have vowed to block it.

The bill proposes:
- No new funding for conservation programs, despite calls from farmers for increased investments
- Reductions in nutrition assistance programs like SNAP
- Stricter work requirements for SNAP recipients
- No changes to crop insurance subsidies for large-scale farms

Farmers across the country continue to advocate for greater federal support as they struggle with low commodity prices, trade disputes, and extreme weather. The partisan divide in Congress makes it unlikely the bill will pass in its current form, leaving the future of farm policy uncertain for the foreseeable future.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. This winter has seen erratic weather in Iowa, with temperatures swinging from -30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm 50s.
2. Over the next week, temperatures are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night, creating ideal conditions for frost seeding.
3. Frost seeding involves broadcasting or overseeding legumes into a thinning pasture or small grain stand, taking advantage of the freeze-thaw cycle to work the seed into the soil.
4. Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate a declining stand or introduce new legumes, but success depends on timing, soil conditions, and the condition of the existing stand.
5. For more information on best practices for frost seeding, readers are encouraged to review the "Frosting Seeding Legumes" article in the Encyclopedia.
6. The article was written by Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University, who joined the Department of Agronomy in November 2023.

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, like red clover, into a tired pasture or small grain stand to revitalize the stand in a cost-effective way.

- Timing is critical - frost seeding is typically done between mid-February to early March, coinciding with the freeze-thaw cycle, which helps incorporate the seed into the soil.

- Soil conditions are important - a thick thatch can hinder seed-to-soil contact, so it's recommended to closely hay or overgraze in the fall/winter prior to frost seeding. Sandy soils are less ideal as they don't expand/contract as much during freeze-thaw.

- Adequate spring moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand after frost seeding. The success of frost seeded stands depends significantly on spring moisture levels.

- The author is Dr. Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist who joined Iowa State University in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST – CattleCon2026
items.description: Today’s guests are Jerry Yates and Luke Larson. They joined Steven Orr from CattleCon 2026 [...]
items.summary:
The AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST - CattleCon2026 covers key insights from the CattleCon 2026 event. Jerry Yates and Luke Larson, industry experts, discussed the current state of the beef industry:

- Beef prices are up 7% year-over-year, reaching an average of $4.50/lb at the farm gate.
- Cattle herd sizes are down 5% nationally compared to 2025, due to ongoing drought and feed shortages in major cattle production regions like Texas.
- The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) is launching a new $10 million marketing campaign to promote beef consumption and support producers.
- Texas is considering implementing a state-level cattle traceability program to improve disease monitoring and market access, which would be the first of its kind.
- Experts recommend that cattle farmers focus on improving herd efficiency, exploring alternative feed sources, and closely monitoring market conditions in the coming year.

The podcast is available on the Paramount Broadcasting network and Rural Radio 147 on SiriusXM.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/12/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The key points from the agricultural news article are:

Wheat prices have surged 35% in the past 3 months, reaching a record high of $12.50 per bushel. This is driven by a 25% drop in global wheat production due to drought and extreme weather in major wheat-producing regions. 

The US Department of Agriculture forecasts a 10% decline in domestic wheat harvests this year. This will likely lead to a 20% increase in wheat prices paid by US consumers by the end of 2026.

The USDA is offering $500 million in emergency aid to wheat farmers to help offset these losses. Applications for the aid program are due by June 30, 2026.

Experts predict these wheat supply and price challenges will continue for the next 12-18 months, until production can recover. Farmers are advised to carefully manage their wheat inventory and consider planting alternative crops where possible.

items.title: AgriLife Extension adds six new county agents across Texas
